results.title: A Dairyland Romance
results.creator_credit: Victoria. Dept. of Agriculture, Keith Harrison and Jack Keane
results.brief_description:
Story revolves around the importance of choosing breeding partners that have good breeding themselves and the benefits that this will bring their offspring. It stars two cows with human characteristics (standing on two legs, wearing clothes, speaking english, etc.) being interviewed about their successful partnership together and goes on to give information on correct rearing techniques. Hand-painted animation looks suberb and the deadpan delivery of the main charcaters is very amusing.

Illustrated ‘The End’ and opening titles.

results.creator_credit: Harvey Spencer, Bill Scholer, Garry Holt and Sportmaster Programs

results.title: The Host Monogama
results.brief_description:
Determination will get you anywhere but tread carefully.

This short film was created by students of the Centre for Animation and Interactive Media (AIM) at RMIT University in Melbourne. Featuring hand-illustrated characters and settings, animated using a paper cutout technique.

results.title: Possums of Bonegilla
results.creator_credit: ACMI Digital Storytelling and Agnes Karlik
results.brief_description: Agnes talks of her migrant experience including her time spent at Bonegilla. She especially focuses on friendships made during those early years of alienation and loneliness.

results.title: Always a farmer
results.brief_description:
A personal account created by a participant in the ACMI Digital Storytelling Workshop “Against the Grain” in association with Partners in Grain (PING).
Not just a farmer’s wife, Jenny Grigg, mother of four and business partner in all ways with her husband on their Mallee sheep and grain farm discovered a group of women who were to change Jenny’s life forever.
This story is dedicated to that network of women (PinG) who help and support other farming women in grains by providing inspiration and encouragement and a feeling of self-worth.

group.title: Against the grain: digital storytelling project

results.title: Green Fingers: Drainage
results.brief_description: ‘Green Fingers’ was a series of short instructional films on home gardening tips, produced by the Victorian Department of Agriculture. In this episode, ‘Drainage’, gardener Rod Cantrill describes the importance of well-drained soil in the home garden. Cantrill demonstrates how to lay agricultural drainage pipes to remove excess water from the soil, and how to raise garden beds as an alternative method. The episodes of ‘Green Fingers’ are an early example of popular gardening shows in the tradition of ‘Sow What’, ‘Better Homes and Gardens’, and ‘Gardening Australia’.

The episodes of Green Fingers are an early example of popular gardening shows in the tradition of Sow What, Better Homes and Gardens, and Gardening Australia.

results.title: Faces
results.brief_description:
Sue Ford’s experimental film “Faces” consists of portraits of the artist and her friends and acquaintances. Ford filmed each subject for roughly 25 seconds, using a wind-up Bolex camera that framed their faces in close-up. Variously self-conscious, serious, amused and distracted, the camera captures every small gesture, expression and flicker of emotion on the person’s face. The result is an examination of portraiture and the performance of identity, demonstrating the artist’s interest in using the camera to capture reality, time and change.

Participants in the film include artists Micky Allan, Bonita Ely and Paul Reed, among others.
results.description:
Sue Ford’s experimental film Faces consists of portraits of the artist and her friends and acquaintances. Each subject is framed in close-up and filmed for roughly 25 seconds at a time. Variously self-conscious, serious, nonchalant, curious, amused and distracted, the camera captures every small gesture, expression and flicker of emotion on the person’s face. The result is an examination of portraiture and the performance of identity, demonstrating the artist’s interest in using the camera to capture reality, time and change.

Participants in the film include artists Micky Allan, Bonita Ely and Paul Reed, among others.
description_for_label:

The result is an examination of portraiture and the performance of identity, demonstrating the artist’s interest in using the camera to capture reality, time and change.

Participants in the film include artists Micky Allan, Bonita Ely and Paul Reed, among others.

results.title: Green Fingers: Weed Control
results.brief_description: ‘Green Fingers’ was a series of short instructional films on home gardening tips, produced by the Victorian Department of Agriculture. In this episode, ‘Weed Control’, gardener Rod Cantrill demonstrates how to control weeds in the home garden. Cantrill shows a range of methods for managing weeds, including hoeing, mulching and herbicides, accompanied by a narrator who explains the benefits and correct techniques of each method. The episodes of ‘Green Fingers’ are an early example of popular gardening shows in the tradition of ‘Sow What’, ‘Better Homes and Gardens’, and ‘Gardening Australia’.

results.title: Green Fingers: Planting Evergreens
results.brief_description: ‘Green Fingers’ was a series of short instructional films on home gardening tips, produced by the Victorian Department of Agriculture. In this episode, ‘Planting Evergreens’, gardener Rod Cantrill demonstrates how to correctly plant evergreen trees and shrubs in your garden, accompanied by a narrator explaining the method and techniques. The episodes of ‘Green Fingers’ are an early example of popular gardening shows in the tradition of ‘Sow What’, ‘Better Homes and Gardens’, and ‘Gardening Australia’.

The episodes of Green Fingers are an early example of popular gardening shows in the tradition of Sow What, Better Homes and Gardens, and Gardening Australia.

results.title: The Melbourne Concert Hall
results.creator_credit: David Greig, David Morgan, The Victorian Arts Centre and Kestrel Films (Australia)
results.brief_description: Interviews with architects, administrators, interior designers, construction workers and others associated with the construction of the Melbourne Concert Hall. Artists who have performed at the venue also give their opinion of hall. Those interviewed include: Roy Ground, Neil Haysom, Theodore Schultz, Ken Myer, John Truscott and Kenny Christophers. Shows segments from performances by Jackie Love, Cleo Laine, Sylvio Gualdo, Karen Knowles, London Early Music Group, Mondo Rock, the guitarist John Williams, Brian May’s Melbourne Showband and conductors Piero Gamba, Patrick Thomas and John Hopkins. Views of Melbourne’s skyline capture the Gas and Fuel buildings that were demolished to accommodate Federation Square.

Shows segments from performances by Jackie Love, Cleo Laine, Sylvio Gualdo, Karen Knowles, London Early Music Group, Mondo Rock, the guitarist John Williams, Brian May’s Melbourne Showband and conductors Piero Gamba, Patrick Thomas and John Hopkins. Views of Melbourne’s skyline capture the Gas and Fuel buildings that were demolished to accommodate Federation Square.
